IPEI
IP Header
Packet Payload
Ethernet Header
Interface Name

2. IP Header and Packet Payload
3. IP Head, Packet Payload, and Ethernet Header
4-6 is the same - just add "Interface Name" to the end of each.

Verbosity Level 5

Selected Answer: ACE
Verbose levels in detail:
 
1: print header of packets
2: print header and data from IP of packets
3: print header and data from Ethernet of packets
4: print header of packets with interface name
5: print header and data from IP of packets with interface name
6: print header and data from Ethernet of packets with interface name
This article walks through some examples and different levels of verbosity to show the different possibilities for debugging.

comments.content: It canÂ´t be C because it states that the remote peer doesnt support Dynamic DNS. It also says that the peer Ip is dynamic, that means that it changes from time to time, so you need to consider as unknow, otherwise you should change your side configuration each time the peer Ip changes,

i think it's Dialup ( B ) 

in the diagram on that page the "left side map" of the users are "dialup clients" the diagram on the right show "Remote peers" with IP that are set by the FQDN. (A & C)


also in the line it says "....use Dynamic IP address, and no Dynamic DNS...." so you would set the IPsec VPN as dial up. the question says "remote peer IP address is dynamic and not support dynamic DNS." so the vpn will be a dialup. 

hope that make sense.

discussion.content:
Correct Answer: C 
B is not correct. Because Dialup user is used when the remote peer`s IP address us unkown. The remote peer whose IP address is unknow acts as the dialup client, and this is often the case for Branch offices and mobile VPN clients that use Dynamic IP address, and no Dynamic DNS. 
C Is correct answer. Static IP address or Dynamic DNS are used when you know the remote peersâs address. If you select static IP address, then you nedd to provide an IP address. If you select Dynamic DNS, then you need to provide a fully qualifield domain name (FQDN)

C is correct. FortiGate_Infrastructure_6.4 page 219

comments.content: Same screenshoot on FGT study guide 6 p127. Key is that same ports are used for both ingress and egress address. This one to one. Answer D

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Selected Answer: B
Might I suggest that Destination NAT being disabled is actually the only conclusive true statement? Speaking of SNAT, default "use interface ip address", and running the same command, shows that some sessions where SNAT is applied might keep source-port intact, its assumed that it will overload and start applying PAT at some point, but it doesn't actually always occur. In fact you can set the policy to preserve source-port, even while configuring dynamic pool with overload and (naturally) one-to-one. C and D can both generate the same output in the end if we can't see the policy configuration... IMHO

comments.content: no way, your stamtment is true , Overload not always do PAT when there are few sessionst.But you can't enable DNAT in the firewall policy... so the answere is D. moreover you cant say it's ovlerload nor Port block allocation beacuse they are same pool type.

one to one
10.1.0.1 SNAT 10.200.1.1
10.1.0.2 SNAT 10.200.1.2
etc....

overload :
10.1.0.1 SNAT 10.200.1.1
10.1.0.2 SNAT 10.200.1.1
etc....
but here we have only one source... It's impossible to compare overload vs one-to-one ?
